head.title: Sept. 24-30: Bosnia; The Three Warring Parties Ponder Life After War

hedline.hl1: Sept. 24-30: Bosnia; The Three Warring Parties Ponder Life After War

block.p: Call it bulldozer diplomacy. Using a combination of flattery, persuasion, pressure, but mostly threats, the United States, led by the negotiator Richard C. Holbrooke, got the three warring parties in Bosnia to sign a statement on the creation of a collective presidency, a parliament and free elections.

The tortuously-worded statement, which even Mr. Holbrooke described as "too vague" and "not a legal document," does not resolve how a new Bosnian Government would actually function or what would be the relationship between Bosnia and the Serb republic that is supposed to sit within its borders.

Call it bulldozer diplomacy. Using a combination of flattery, persuasion, pressure, but mostly threats, the United States, led by the negotiator Richard C. Holbrooke, got the three warring parties in Bosnia to sign a statement on the creation of a collective presidency, a parliament and free elections.

The tortuously-worded statement, which even Mr. Holbrooke described as "too vague" and "not a legal document," does not resolve how a new Bosnian Government would actually function or what would be the relationship between Bosnia and the Serb republic that is supposed to sit within its borders.
But for now, momentum seems to be more important than precision. "When we can't get agreement on something, we keep going," Mr. Holbrooke said. ELAINE SCIOLINO
